pull.title: contrib/install_db4.sh: http_get if tar.gz does not exist

events.body:
> ```
> ./contrib/install_db4.sh `pwd`
> ```
> 
> fails if db-4.8.30.NC.tar.gz exists

Then there is something wrong in lines 54 and 55, right?

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/77a2f5d30c5ecb764b8a7c098492e1f5cdec90f0/contrib/install_db4.sh#L54-L55

The fix would be in those two lines, not out of the scope of http_get.

How does it fail exactly?

rename.to: contrib/install_db4.sh: http_get if tar.gz does not exist

events.body: I don't understand - isn't the existing file case already covered in `http_get`? https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/contrib/install_db4.sh#L54-L55

More generally,
could only apply tar extraction unconditionally if http_get performs
an infinite loop broken when the file is downloaded, not only downloaded but until sha256_check is satisfactory as well, keeping trying new downloads on corrupted download or unexpected content.

Or do http_get and sha256_check abort the whole script when returning unsuccessfully?
Closed - Maybe there was an anomily with MacOS M1 bash shell or the download was being corrupted (thru a vpn).

comments.body: So this will skip the BDB_HASH check?

For the current logic it would imo be better to write it as a negation so that the `tar` can be factored out:
```bash
if [ ! -f "${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz" ]; then
    http_get "${BDB_URL}" "${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz" "${BDB_HASH}"
fi
tar -xzvf ${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz -C "$BDB_PREFIX"
```
I agree that checking the hash would make (some) sense even if the file exists, though.

> For the current logic it would imo be better to write it as a negation so that the `tar` can be factored out:
> 
> ```shell
> if [ ! -f "${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz" ]; then
>     http_get "${BDB_URL}" "${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz" "${BDB_HASH}"
> fi
> tar -xzvf ${BDB_VERSION}.tar.gz -C "$BDB_PREFIX"
> ```

That suggestion is good if http_get exits upon failure.

You are not proposing any error control on the tar exit status,
are you? It would fail if http_get fails what is supposed to do.
